questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : APTITUDE (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" MANDATORILY YOU HAVE TO ATTEND ALL THE SECTIONS
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : APTITUDE (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" MANDATORILY YOU HAVE TO ATTEND ALL THE SECTIONS

questions.question_text_1: Anil started walking 400 meters straight from his office. He then turned right and walked 300 meters. He turned right and walked another 100 meters to reach his house. If his house is South-East from his office, then in which direction did Anil start walking from the office?
question_texts: Anil started walking 400 meters straight from his office. He then turned right and walked 300 meters. He turned right and walked another 100 meters to reach his house. If his house is South-East from his office, then in which direction did Anil start walking from the office?

questions.question_text_1: If a car travels 60 miles per hour for 2 hours, and then travels 40 miles per hour for 3 hours, what is the average speed of the car over the entire trip?
question_texts: If a car travels 60 miles per hour for 2 hours, and then travels 40 miles per hour for 3 hours, what is the average speed of the car over the entire trip?

questions.question_text_1: Pointing to a man in a photograph, Suresh said, “His father is the only son of my father.” How is Suresh related to the man in the photograph?
question_texts: Pointing to a man in a photograph, Suresh said, “His father is the only son of my father.” How is Suresh related to the man in the photograph?

questions.question_text_1:
Suppose there are four letters and four envelopes and exactly one letter is to be put in one envelope with the correct address. If the letters are randomly inserted into the envelopes, then consider the following two statements: 
(1) It is possible that exactly one letter goes into an incorrect envelope. (2) It is possible that exactly one letter goes into a correct envelope. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
question_texts:
Suppose there are four letters and four envelopes and exactly one letter is to be put in one envelope with the correct address. If the letters are randomly inserted into the envelopes, then consider the following two statements: 
(1) It is possible that exactly one letter goes into an incorrect envelope. (2) It is possible that exactly one letter goes into a correct envelope. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?

questions.question_text_1: In a certain code language, if “CAT” is coded as “DBU”, and “DOG” is coded as “EPH”, then how is “MOUSE” coded?
question_texts: In a certain code language, if “CAT” is coded as “DBU”, and “DOG” is coded as “EPH”, then how is “MOUSE” coded?

questions.question_text_1: Three statements are given followed by three conclusions I, II and III. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to contradict commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions follows from the given statements. Statements: • All Bats are Rats. • Some Rats are snakes. • No snakes are bats. Conclusions: I. All snakes are Rats. II. Some Rats are not Bats. III. No bats are snakes.
question_texts: Three statements are given followed by three conclusions I, II and III. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to contradict commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions follows from the given statements. Statements: • All Bats are Rats. • Some Rats are snakes. • No snakes are bats. Conclusions: I. All snakes are Rats. II. Some Rats are not Bats. III. No bats are snakes.

questions.question_text_1: Three statements are given followed by three conclusions I, II and III. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to contradict commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions follows from the given statements. Statements: • All Carrots are Onions. • Some Potatoes are Carrots. • All Tomatoes are Potatoes. Conclusions: I. All Carrots are Tomatoes II. Some Tomatoes are Onions. III. Some Onions are Potatoes
question_texts: Three statements are given followed by three conclusions I, II and III. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to contradict commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions follows from the given statements. Statements: • All Carrots are Onions. • Some Potatoes are Carrots. • All Tomatoes are Potatoes. Conclusions: I. All Carrots are Tomatoes II. Some Tomatoes are Onions. III. Some Onions are Potatoes

questions.question_text_1: If A takes 12 days to complete a task and B takes 18 days to complete the same task, how long will it take for A and B to finish the task if they work together?
question_texts: If A takes 12 days to complete a task and B takes 18 days to complete the same task, how long will it take for A and B to finish the task if they work together?

questions.question_text_1: The ages of A, B, and C are in the ratio of 5:7:9. After 5 years, the sum of their ages will be 120 years. What is the present age of C?
question_texts: The ages of A, B, and C are in the ratio of 5:7:9. After 5 years, the sum of their ages will be 120 years. What is the present age of C?

questions.question_text_1: The average weight of 10 students in a class is 45 kg. When the weight of a teacher is included, the average weight of the 11 people becomes 46 kg. What is the weight of the teacher?
question_texts: The average weight of 10 students in a class is 45 kg. When the weight of a teacher is included, the average weight of the 11 people becomes 46 kg. What is the weight of the teacher?

questions.question_text_1: The cost price of 15 chocolates is the same as the selling price of n chocolates. If the total profit obtained is 25%, then find the value of n.
question_texts: The cost price of 15 chocolates is the same as the selling price of n chocolates. If the total profit obtained is 25%, then find the value of n.

questions.question_text_1: Let AB and CD be two digit numbers such that A,B,C, and D are distinct nonzero digits. If AB + CD = 183, then find the value of A + B + C + D.
question_texts: Let AB and CD be two digit numbers such that A,B,C, and D are distinct nonzero digits. If AB + CD = 183, then find the value of A + B + C + D.

questions.question_text_1: If a cube painted on all six faces is cut into 27 smaller cubes of equal volume, then how many of these small cubes will have exactly two sides painted?
question_texts: If a cube painted on all six faces is cut into 27 smaller cubes of equal volume, then how many of these small cubes will have exactly two sides painted?

questions.question_text_1:
Study the information carefully and answer the given subquestions:

Five boxes A,B,C,D, and E are stacked one above the other, but not necessarily in the same order. Each box contains a different type of fruit: Pineapple, Mango, Papaya, Banana, and Guava. The following conditions apply: 
• There is exactly one box between Box E and the box that contains Mango. • There are exactly two boxes between the box that contains Pineapple and the one that contains Banana. • The box that contains Papaya is placed immediately below the box that contains Banana. • There are exactly two boxes between Box E and Box B, which contains Banana. • Box A is placed immediately above Box C.
question_texts:
Study the information carefully and answer the given subquestions:

Five boxes A,B,C,D, and E are stacked one above the other, but not necessarily in the same order. Each box contains a different type of fruit: Pineapple, Mango, Papaya, Banana, and Guava. The following conditions apply: 
• There is exactly one box between Box E and the box that contains Mango. • There are exactly two boxes between the box that contains Pineapple and the one that contains Banana. • The box that contains Papaya is placed immediately below the box that contains Banana. • There are exactly two boxes between Box E and Box B, which contains Banana. • Box A is placed immediately above Box C.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following box is placed immediately below box C?
question_texts: Which of the following box is placed immediately below box C?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and equations** for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

### **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **A. Logical Reasoning & Puzzles**
- **Directional Problems** (e.g., Q2):
  - Cardinal directions (North, South, East, West).
  - Right/left turns and relative positioning.
- **Blood Relations** (e.g., Q4):
  - Family tree diagrams (father, son, brother, uncle).
  - Decoding statements like *"His father is the only son of my father"* → Suresh is the father.
- **Coding-Decoding** (e.g., Q7):
  - Letter shifting (e.g., CAT → DBU: each letter +1).
  - Pattern recognition (e.g., MOUSE → NPVTF: M→N, O→P, U→V, S→T, E→F).
- **Syllogism** (e.g., Q8, Q9):
  - Venn diagrams for statements like *"All Bats are Rats"* or *"Some Potatoes are Carrots."*
  - Validating conclusions (e.g., *"No snakes are bats"* → Conclusion III is valid).
- **Arrangement Puzzles** (e.g., Q17–Q21):
  - Stacking/sequencing with constraints (e.g., *"Box A is above Box C"*).
  - Eliminating options based on conditions (e.g., *"Papaya is below Banana"*).

#### **B. Mathematics**
- **Average Speed** (e.g., Q3):
  - Formula:
    \[
    \text{Average Speed} = \frac{\text{Total Distance}}{\text{Total Time}}
    \]
    Example: \((60 \times 2 + 40 \times 3) / (2 + 3) = 48\) mph.
- **Work Rate** (e.g., Q10):
  - Combined work rate:
    \[
    \frac{1}{T} = \frac{1}{T_A} + \frac{1}{T_B} \quad \text{(e.g., } \frac{1}{12} + \frac{1}{18} = \frac{5}{36} \Rightarrow T = 7.2 \text{ days)}
    \]
- **Ratios & Ages** (e.g., Q6, Q11):
  - Solving linear equations from ratios:
    - Q6: \(p = q + 3\), \(q = 6\) → \(B = 3p + 2q = 39\).
    - Q11: Let ages be \(5x, 7x, 9x\). After 5 years: \(5x + 7x + 9x + 15 = 120\) → \(x = 3\), so \(C = 27 + 5 = 32\) (but answer is 45; recheck).
- **Profit & Loss** (e.g., Q14):
  - Profit percentage:
    \[
    \text{Profit} = \frac{\text{SP} - \text{CP}}{\text{CP}} \times 100\%
    \]
    Given 25% profit on CP of 15 chocolates = SP of \(n\) chocolates:
    \[
    1.25 \times \text{CP}_{15} = \text{SP}_n \Rightarrow n = 12
    \]
- **Algebraic Operations** (e.g., Q13):
  - Decoding symbols (\(\otimes, \boxminus, \triangle\)) as \(+, -, \times, \div\).
  - Example: \(8 \otimes 4 \boxminus 9 = 44\) → Likely \(8 \times 4 + 9 = 41\) (doesn’t fit). Alternative: \(8 \times 4 + (9 \times 1) = 41\) (inconsistent). **Answer is 13**, suggesting \(\otimes = \times\), \(\triangle = -\), \(\boxminus = +\):
    \[
    10 \times 15 - 5 = 145 \quad (\text{Not 13. Re-evaluate.})
    \]
    *Clarification needed.*
- **Combinatorics** (e.g., Q5):
  - Derangements: Exactly one correct letter in envelopes is possible (e.g., ADCB), but exactly one incorrect is impossible (others must also be incorrect).
- **Geometry** (e.g., Q16):
  - Painted cube division: For a \(3 \times 3 \times 3\) cube, small cubes with **2 painted faces** are on edges but not corners:
    \[
    12 \text{ edges} \times (3 - 2) \text{ cubes/edge} = 12
    \]

#### **C. Data Interpretation**
- **Averages** (e.g., Q12):
  - New average with added data point:
    \[
    \text{Teacher's weight} = 11 \times 46 - 10 \times 45 = 56 \text{ kg}
    \]
- **Digit Problems** (e.g., Q15):
  - Two-digit numbers: \(AB + CD = 183\) where \(A,B,C,D\) are distinct (1–9).
    Solution: \(97 + 86 = 183\) → Sum of digits \(9 + 7 + 8 + 6 = 30\).

---

### **2. Key Equations**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Average Speed           | \(\text{Average Speed} = \frac{\text{Total Distance}}{\text{Total Time}}\) |
| Work Rate               | \(\frac{1}{T} = \frac{1}{T_A} + \frac{1}{T_B}\)                            |
| Profit Percentage       | \(\text{Profit}\% = \left(\frac{\text{SP} - \text{CP}}{\text{CP}}\right) \times 100\) |
| Ratio Problems          | If \(A:B:C = k_1:k_2:k_3\), then \(A = k_1x\), \(B = k_2x\), etc.         |
| Painted Cube            | 2-faced cubes: \(12 \times (n - 2)\) for \(n \times n \times n\) cube.     |
| Derangements             | \(D_n = n! \sum_{i=0}^n \frac{(-1)^i}{i!}\) (for Q5, use logic instead).   |

---

### **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Logical Reasoning Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Logical Reasoning] --> B[Directional Problems]
    A --> C[Blood Relations]
    A --> D[Coding-Decoding]
    A --> E[Syllogism]
    A --> F[Arrangement Puzzles]
    B --> B1[Cardinal Directions]
    B --> B2[Turns Right/Left]
    C --> C1[Family Trees]
    C --> C2[Statement Decoding]
    D --> D1[Letter Shifting]
    D --> D2[Pattern Recognition]
    E --> E1[Venn Diagrams]
    E --> E2[Conclusion Validation]
    F --> F1[Stacking Constraints]
    F --> F2[Elimination of Options]
```

#### **Graph 2: Mathematical Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    G[Mathematics] --> H[Average Speed]
    G --> I[Work Rate]
    G --> J[Ratios & Ages]
    G --> K[Profit & Loss]
    G --> L[Algebraic Operations]
    G --> M[Combinatorics]
    G --> N[Geometry]
    H --> H1[Total Distance/Time]
    I --> I1[Combined Work Formula]
    J --> J1[Linear Equations]
    J --> J2[Ratio Proportions]
    K --> K1[Profit Percentage]
    L --> L1[Symbol Decoding]
    M --> M1[Derangements]
    N --> N1[Painted Cube Formula]
```

#### **Graph 3: Data Interpretation**
```mermaid
graph TD
    O[Data Interpretation] --> P[Averages]
    O --> Q[Digit Problems]
    P --> P1[New Average Calculation]
    Q --> Q1[Two-Digit Number Sum]
```

---

### **4. Exam Tips**
1. **Directional Problems**: Draw a diagram to track movements (e.g., Q2: East → Right → South-East).
2. **Syllogism**: Draw Venn diagrams for each statement before evaluating conclusions.
3. **Work Rate**: Always invert individual times to add rates (e.g., \(1/12 + 1/18\)).
4. **Coding-Decoding**: Check for consistent patterns (e.g., +1 shift for each letter).
5. **Painted Cubes**: Memorize the formula for 2-faced cubes: \(12 \times (n - 2)\).
6. **Profit & Loss**: Ensure CP and SP are clearly distinguished (Q14: CP of 15 = SP of 12).
7. **Arrangement Puzzles**: List constraints vertically and eliminate options step-by-step.
